title: Document: Man accused of demanding money, drugs before fatal Corpus Christi shooting
summary:
A 31-year-old man is accused of entering a Corpus Christi home and demanding money and drugs before a fatal shooting, an arrest affidavit says.
David Sanchez, 52, was fatally shot inside a Corpus Christi home on Jan. 12, 2020.
(Photo: Screenshot)About 10:30 p.m. Jan. 12, Corpus Christi police responded to a report of a shooting on Meuly.
The man told police he was in the kitchen of the home with another person when someone knocked on the door.
The man told police he heard a single gunshot before Sanchez fell, the document states.

summary:

title: Police investigate overnight shooting
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — One person is recovering following an overnight shooting.
It happened just after 1:30 a.m. Tuesday outside of a home at the corner of Baldwin and Sarita.
That's where Corpus Christi Police found a 40 year-old-man who appeared to have been shot twice in the stomach.
He was taken to the hospital and is expected to be okay.

title: Home invasion sends homeowner to the hospital
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — A local man has been released from the hospital after being attacked during a home invasion.
The victim said that he was attacked by three men who pounded on his door, claiming they were Drug Enforcement Agency agents.
One neighbor who was already calling police told him to run to the Stripes store on the corner of Staples and Doddridge.
A store clerk called police and the victim was taken to the hospital and later released.
He said he is doing okay but has no idea who entered his home.

title: Experts: LNG is going to be cheaper in 2020. Here's why and how that could affect Texas
summary:
Liquified natural gas is forecast to trade for much less in 2020.
In its January 2020 Short-Term Energy Outlook, the Energy Information Administration predicted average U.S. natural gas prices will be 9% lower in 2020 than in 2019.
Increased production of natural gas should meet the growing domestic and global demand for clean natural gas, said Todd Staples, president of the Texas Oil and Gas Association.
Experts are predicting record volumes of U.S. dry natural gas production to continue through 2020, from an estimated 92.0 billion cubic feet per day in 2019 to 94.7 billion Bcf/d in 2020.
In 2021, EIA expects industrial sector consumption to flatten because of higher industrial sector natural gas prices.

title: Texas facing shortage of 60,000 nurses
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The Texas Department of State Health Services is predicting a major shortage of nurses over the next 10 years.
In Texas, we're looking at a shortage of 60,000 nurses, and a million nationwide by 2029.
While the number of nursing students at TAMUCC's nursing program continues to grow, its faculty and clinical space resources remain the same.
One of the issues universities and hospitals are seeing with the nursing shortage is students and young nurses burning out.
After pushing through one of the most rigorous nursing programs in Texas, TAMUCC nurses are now reaping the benefits.

summary:

Members unanimously voted in favor to the motion, which from this day forward declares the third Monday of each January as Martin Luther King Civil Rights Day of Service.

title: Boat crashes into gas platform, sinks
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, TEXAS — Two fishermen were rescued from the waters after their boat crashed into a gas platform.
The crash happened in the waters close to the Cos Way Bait & Tackle around 2:55 am Friday.
2 said a fisherman fishing from a pier heard a 24-foot boat pass by and then heard a loud crash.
It took search crews 15 minutes to discover two men who were holding on to a gas platform.
Game Wardens with Texas Parks and Wildlife will investigate the boat crash.

title: DPS: 2 men from north Texas killed in head-on crash in Bee County
summary:
CLOSE More than 900 people who died in a crash in Texas in 2017 were not wearing a seat belt.

Texas Department of Public Safety officials believe the crash happened about 9:56 a.m. on U.S. Highway 181, south of Normanna in Bee County, according to a news release.
Authorities believe a 2017 Peterbilt semi-trailer, driven by a man, was traveling south on U.S. 181.
For reasons unknown, the semi-trailer veered into the northbound lane of U.S. 181, where it struck a 2009 Dodge Ram pickup head-on, the release states.

title: Jasper N. Rogen
summary:
JASPER N. ROGENCedar RapidsJasper N. Rogen, 97, of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, formerly of rural Waukon, died Saturday, April 11, 2020, at The Gardens of Cedar Rapids, where he had lived for the past two years.
Jasper Norman Rogen was born on the family farm on Oct. 16, 1922, to George and Ruby (Hanson) Rogen.
In March 1969, they sold the livestock and machinery for the elevators and escalators of the city life in Cedar Rapids.
Surviving are his wife of 75 years, Leverne; his children, Donald (Susan) Rogen of Cedar Rapids, John Rogen of Des Moines, Susan (Rick) Rissman of Cedar Rapids and Gerald (Natalie) Rogen of Corpus Christi, Texas; his sister, Eva Lou Wise of Palatine, Ill.; grandchildren, Cathy (Jason) Mahan, Barb Rogen, Jason Rissman, Shannon (Mark) Debner and Natasha Rogen; and great-grandchildren, Nichole and Hayley Mahan, Sydney and Sabryna Rissman, and Madison Debner.
Jasper was preceded in death by his parents; daughter, Janice Rogen; granddaughter, Kristine Rogen; and grandson, Kip Rogen.

title: From medical bills to tax relief, here are the new laws in Texas starting Jan. 1
authors: John C Moritz Austin Bureau Usa Today Network
summary:
AUSTIN — A new law designed to protect consumers from surprise sky-high medical bills when they are treated by an out-of-network medical provider almost went on the books with its teeth yanked out.
Senate Bill 1264 is one of a handful of Texas laws that take effect when the calendar page turns to 2020 on Wednesday.
It was nearly gutted when the Texas Medical Board sought to carve out an exception allowing high-priced billing to stand for out-of-network care if patients signed a waiver.
Medical debt: 3 mistakes to avoidThe medical board, the state agency that regulates physicians and physician assistants, got the message.
The measure was enacted in response to high-profile examples of sexual violence at colleges and universities that went unreported and unpunished.

title: What will flat crude oil prices in 2020 mean for Texas?
summary:
The U.S. Energy Information Administration predicts the Brent crude oil spot price will average $65 per barrel in 2020 and $68/b in 2021.
The agency expects crude oil prices to remain elevated in the first few months of 2020, a trend that it said reflected a response to "recent geopolitical events."
Soft crude oil prices has forced companies like Gulf Marine to re-evaluate staff and production levels the last two years.
"With so much oil in our backyard, you can imagine how shale oil operators would react if world oil prices were up," Lee said.
Texas shale oil and gasoline are flooding the markets, especially in South Texas."

title: Local flu cases skyrocket compared to previous year
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — It may be a brand new year, but unfortunately we didn't leave the flu season behind.
If anything, it continues to get worse.
According to the city/county health department, 749 confirmed cases of the flu were reported in the last full week of 2019.
Compare that to the same time period a year ago, when a total of 155 confirmed cases were reported.
And there's more bad news as the flu season typically doesn't hit its peak until February or March.

summary:

"We wanna provide service to the community that is meaningful to them," CCRTA CEO Jorge Cruz-Aedo said.

title: Port of Corpus Christi sees best year ever
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The Port of Corpus Christi moved more tons of cargo last year than any other year of its existence.
"Twenty-nineteen was the best year in the history of the Port of Corpus Christi -- in the 93-year history of the Port of Corpus Christi," Port Authority Chairman Charles Zahn said.
The Port moved 122.2 million cargo tons in 2019 -- 16 million more than the previous record-year of 2018.
Oil from petroleum-rich West Texas became easier to receive at the port last year.
"(The port is) absolutely the largest sector of our economy," Corpus Christi Regional Economic Development Corporation President and CEO Iain Vasey said.

The flames reached a nearby home, at 6049 Edgewater, and it was that home where flames reignited Thursday morning.
The fire was discovered by officers with the Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi Police Department around 2:25 a.m. Thursday.

title: Dozens take a plunge for the fight against ALS
summary:
For the sixth year, North Beach and Fajitaville hosted the Corpus Christi Polar Bear Plunge.
Corpus Christi’s plunge helps fund the fight against Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, better known as ALS.
While there's no cure for ALS, organizers believe every dollar they raise gets doctors a little closer to finding one.
“I had never done a Polar Plunge before,” said Scott Robinson of Spokane, Wash. “From our point of view, with the weather so nice and warm, why not?”Whether it was their first plunge or sixth, everyone was there to help the fight against ALS.
“It means an awful lot, we're a small community of people with ALS here,” said Bob Chapman, whose wife is battling ALS.

title: Fire claims house near Crosstown Expressway
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Corpus Christi firefighters made quick work of a house fire that erupted at the corner of 17th Street and Prescott on Wednesday night.
Johnson said when they firefighters arrived, the small home near the Crosstown Expressway was fully engulfed, with heavy fire and smoke escaping from the front and rear of the building.
The fire broke out shortly after 9 p.m. and was controlled within 10 minutes without incident.
No injuries were reported and Johnson said the house's tenant was not there when the fire broke out.
The Red Cross has been called in to arrange for temporary housing.

title: Selena Quintanilla's father: Fiesta de la Flor officially canceled
summary:
CLOSE Check out some of the best (and our favorite) moments from Fiesta de la Flor 2019: Day 2 in Corpus Christi.
There will be no more Fiesta de la Flor.
Abraham Quintanilla, Selena's father, told the Caller-Times in a phone call Tuesday that last year's Fiesta de la Flor, a two-day music festival honoring Selena, was "the last one."
Fiesta de la Flor began in Corpus Christi, Selena's hometown, in 2015.
In October, the Quintanilla family told the Corpus Christi Convention & Visitors Bureau they would not authorize the festival in Corpus Christi in 2020.

title: Steel Dynamics' plant near Corpus Christi earns Trump's praise at USMCA signing
summary:
CLOSE President Donald Trump signed the new USMCA trade agreement Wednesday, a major rewrite of the trade rules with Canada and Mexico.
Among them was Steel Dynamics' effort to build a $1.9 billion flat roll steel mill near Sinton, about two miles east of the intersection of State Highway 89 and U.S. Highway 77.
The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA, replaces the North American Free Trade Agreement, the act that was adopted in 1994 to govern trade between the three nations.
President Donald Trump speaks before signing the United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement, known as USMCA, during a ceremony on White House South Lawn on Jan. 29, 2020.

title: Driver rescued following single car crash
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, TEXAS — A driver was trapped in his vehicle after a one-car accident early Wednesday morning.
The accident occurred just before 6 a.m. Wednesday at the intersection of Leopard and Josephine Street near City Hall.
The driver was trapped in the vehicle when first responders arrived.
They're not sure what caused the driver to crash.
Power was knocked out to several buildings surrounding the intersection after the accident.

title: 2 men hospitalized after stabbing each other
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Two men are recovering in the hospital after police say they stabbed each other.
The stabbing happened just before 3 p.m., Jan. 4. at a house near the intersection of Kilgore and Alexander.
According to Lieutenant Nicholas Kless, with the Corpus Christi police department, said one of the men wanted to see his ex girlfriend's cell phone and got angry when she refused.
Once he is out of the hospital, that second man will be charged with aggravated assault.
Police also arrested a third man at the house who had outstanding warrants.

title: Police arrest suspects involved in shooting near Cole Park
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Corpus Christi police are investigating a drive-by shooting that locked down a hospital.
The shooting happened near Cole Park around 9:50 pm Thursday.
"Officers received reports of a person was hit by bullet fragments after being shot at where the suspect shot at the ground," Corpus Christi Police Lt. Braden Tackettsaid.
Dispatchers told officers to be on the lookout for a white vehicle suspected of taking part in the shooting.
Officers quickly surrounded the area and pulled a white car over at a gas station near South Alameda Street and Doddridge Street.

title: Boots and Bling Ball spreads awareness for human trafficking, celebrates child survivors
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Braselton Homes will present the Seventh Annual New Life Refuge Ministries Boots and Bling Ball on January 23.
New Life Refuge Ministries has put together this event to celebrate the courage of child survivors of sex trafficking.
There are thousands of victims of human trafficking every year in the Coastal Bend, and this celebration aims to restore those who have been victimized by predators.
Organizers say the attire to the Gala will be boots and bling - Texas chic.
For more information on the Seventh Annual New Life Refuge Ministries Boots and Bling Ball, visit their website of Facebook page.

title: Texas hospitals don't have enough beds for coronavirus patients if too many people get sick at once
summary:
The Texas Tribune interviewed more than a dozen doctors, nurses and other health care workers about how ready the state’s health care system is for an expected spike in coronavirus cases.
Greg Abbott said he was confident that Texas hospitals have enough ventilators to handle the situation.
Texas’ hospital capacity — the number of beds available per person in the general population — is about 2.9 beds per 1,000 Texans, according to state regulators.
Texas health care workers say those figures underscore the need to slow the number of new infections so that hospitals can keep up.
Other health care workers expressed fears that supplies of personal protective equipment, such as N95 respirator masks, could quickly run out.

title: Martha Ballweg Durand
summary:
On Wednesday, April 8, 2020, Martha Ballweg Durand, 90, peacefully passed away in the hospital with her daughter by her side and the love of her family surrounding her.
Martha worked as an operating room nurse at St. Mary’s Hospital in Roswell, New Mexico, where she met the love of her life, Joe Davis Durand.
She was a pillar of her church community, Immaculate Conception Catholic Church, Dexter, New Mexico.
She is preceded in death by her parents, her brothers and sisters, her husband, Joe Davis Durand, their son, Roger Joseph Durand.
She is survived by her daughter, Michelle Durand Runyan of Garland, Texas; daughter-in-law, Sherry Parriera Durand of Dexter, New Mexico; grandchildren, Taylor Durand and fiance Kenda Tucker of Dexter, New Mexico, Ashley Runyan and fiance Florin Constantin of Barcelona, Spain, Alysia Runyan of Garland, Texas, Timothy Durand and wife Cheyenne of Dexter, New Mexico; great-grandchildren: Jayden Runyan, Tristan Runyan-Shirley, Benjamin Runyan-Shirley all of Garland, Texas, Blakeley Harris of Dexter, New Mexico, Grayson Durand of Dexter, New Mexico and many nephews and nieces.

title: Timothy M. Westby
summary:

title: 2020 Great Texas Warrant Roundup is set to begin on February 29th
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — If you have an outstanding warrant with any area law enforcement agency, now is the time to take care of it.
The 2020 Great Texas Warrant Roundup is set to begin on February 29th, but an amnesty period has been set up for the next two weeks.
Beginning Monday, you will be allowed to clear any Class C Misdemeanor outstanding warrants without fear of being arrested.
"The main goal is to help people come in before the warrant roundup starts and resolve these cases," stated Gilbert Hernandez.
Again, the amnesty period will last for two weeks from February 17th through the 28th, and the great warrant roundup will begin on February 29th.

A warrant is a warrant it's you know being directed that somebody has not done something they should've," assistant chief Mark Schauer said.

title: Corpus Christi resident will be celebrating leap year birthday
summary:
On Saturday, February 29, 2020, Miranda Jordan, a Corpus Christi resident, will turn 20, but technically she'll only be 5 years old.
Miranda Jordan was born on a leap year.
"At first when I was little I would be like aw that's not cool but as I started getting older I was like well that's really special," Jordan said.
"Like no one else that I've met has this kind of birthday so I kind of felt special," Miranda said.
"And I tell them ya when I'm really old, I'm not gonna be that old so jokes on you."

title: Fire crews in Corpus Christi battle 150-feet flames after gas line rupture, officials say
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas – Corpus Christi police and fire officials are at the scene of a gas line rupture that has caused flames as high as 150-feet, officials said Monday.
The Corpus Christi Police Department posted on Facebook at 8:51 a.m. that officials were responding to the fire in the area of Interstate Highway 37 and Buddy Lawrence Drive.
Corpus Christi Deputy Fire Chief Richie Quintero said flames coming from the ruptured gas line were nearly 150-feet high.
At 9:41 a.m., police asked residents near the area to shelter in place.
Officials do not know who the line belongs but are working to confirm, Quintero said.

title: Officials remind community that amnesty period will end Friday, Feb. 28 for the 2020 Great Texas Warrant Roundup
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — According to officials, the amnesty period for the 2020 Great Texas Warrant Roundup has already begun.
During the amnesty period, the Municipal Court will have extended hours from 8:00 a.m. to 6:30 p.m., Monday through Friday.
Payment plans and community service hours are available for those who qualify, according to officials.
The Warrant Roundup will officially kick off Monday, February 29 and continue through Friday, March 13, and any unresolved cases at that time could lead to an arrest.
Individuals can find out if they have Municipal Court warrants by visiting https://www.cctexas.com/warrantroundup or by calling 361-826-2500.

title: Cloud: Trump wants $100 million for Port of Corpus Christi widening project in 2021
summary:
CLOSE President Donald Trump wants action when it comes to helping Texas ports, including the Port of Corpus Christi.
Corpus Christi Caller TimesThe Trump administration has included in its 2021 budget proposal $100 million for the Port of Corpus Christi to support its effort to widen and deepen its ship channel.
“I’m thankful President Trump has once again prioritized funding for the Port of Corpus Christi’s Channel Improvement Project in this year’s budget," said Cloud, R-Victoria.
In May, the port formally broke ground on the $380 million project, which aims to widen and deepen the Corpus Christi Ship Channel.
The Port of Corpus Christi intends to widen this entryway, near Port Aransas, that leads into the port.

title: Nuevo Cafe crowned Souper Bowl 2020 champion
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The Souper Bowl 2020, hosted by the Arts Center of Corpus Christi, has crowned a new champion.
The Art Center of Corpus Christi and the Coastal Bend Food Bank teamed up once again for this event.
Local restaurants donated a variety of soups for guests to enjoy and the people voted for their favorite: Nuevo Cafe's Roasted Poblano Soup.
Nuevo Cafe is located at 1124 Ayers St, Corpus Christi, TX 78404.
Attendees walked away from the event with a handcrafted, one-of-a-kind bowl, crafted by the artists of the The Barry Brown Clay Studio.

title: Games of Texas coming back to Corpus Christi, thousands of athletes expected
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The countdown is on for the Games of Texas.
The city of Corpus Christi will be hosting the 2020 Games of Texas from Thursday, July 30 to Sunday, August 2.
Director of Parks and Recreation Jermel Stevenson said the community can expect about 30,000 people to make their way to Corpus Christi during this summer event.
Stevenson said when Corpus Christi hosts these games, they will set the bar high.
The last time Corpus Christi hosted the games of Texas was 2012 and 2013.

title: Here's who the Corpus Christi City Council has tapped to serve on the port authority
summary:

Al Jones, retired CEO and chairman of American Bank, was selected on Tuesday in a split vote by the Corpus Christi City Council to serve the unexpired, 11-month term of former port commissioner Wayne Squires.
He was not appointed in 2015; the City Council appointed Orion Drilling CEO Wayne Squires in a 5-4 vote.
Bell is the sister of County Judge Barbara Canales, who prior to elected office served on the port commission.

title: Brushfire burns about 40 acres in west Corpus Christi
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Firefighters and brush trucks were called to the scene of a stubborn brush fire Friday afternoon on Saratoga and Calle Los Colonias.
City and Nueces County firefighters were also called to the scene to try and contain the blaze that wound up burning about 40 acres of grass.
"it's not gonna extend any further, and with the wind direction from the south.
It doesn't look like it's going impinge on any of the neighborhood, which is what we were really worried about making sure our citizens in Los Colonias are safe," Battalion Chief Daniel Valdez said.
It took about two hours for crews to contain the flames.

title: 2020 Census seeks employees in the Coastal Bend
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The US 2020 Census is hiring for over 4,000 jobs in the Coastal Bend.
The US 2020 Census has seven operations that need to be filled, a large majority of applicants will become field representatives, where a person will go door-to-door to make sure everyone fills out a census.
Positions in the Coastal Bend will pay between $18-19 an hour.
The Census will also pay 58 cents a mile and will compensate for background checks and all training.
To apply for one of the numerous jobs through the 2020 Census, you can go to www.2020census.gov/jobsIt is important that everyone is accounted for through the census because funds granted to the area, will be distributed based on what is needed.

title: Caller-Times endorsements: This is how we're endorsing in the 2020 Texas primary election
summary:
This is an editorial: An editorial, like news reporting, is based on objective facts, but shares an opinion.
The Caller-Times has a long tradition of making editorial board endorsements from the top of the election ballot to the bottom.
But in local races for positions that can have a profound impact on you, our informed opinions become more profound.
We decided that two races were worth seeking face-to-face interviews with the primary election candidates — the Republican primaries for district attorney and 347th District Court.

title: Crime of the Week: Feb. 19
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Detectives want your help to catch these robbery suspects in this week's Corpus Christi Crime Stoppers Crime of the Week.
Police said that at approximately 10:35 p.m. on Tuesday, Feb. 11, three suspects robbed a person on the 400 block of Chaparral St.
The third suspect is described as a black man between 17 and 25 years old, also thin, between 5-10 and 6-feet tall, wearing a gray sweatshirt and sweatpants.
If you can identify these robbery suspects, or have any additional information about this crime, call Crime Stoppers at 888-TIPS or submit the information online at 888TIPS.com.
Crime Stoppers guarantees to keep your identity secret and if the information leads to an arrest, it could earn you up to $2,500 dollars in cash.

title: Local doctor: Flu likely more deadly than coronavirus
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — While admitting we need more information about the COVID-19 coronavirus from China that's spreading worldwide, a local emergency-room doctor believes it eventually will be determined that it is 10 times less deadly than this year's flu strains.
"What the coronavirus that's coming out of China is and what's its capabilities, we're not quite sure," said Dr. Schwirtlich.
His relatively low concern level about COVID-19 coronavirus does not ease the minds of some people who are visiting Corpus Christi.
Other visitors think they know what to do to prevent catching COVID-19 coronavirus, and they're not as concerned.
"If you don't want to have coronavirus is like saying you don't want to have the flu," said Genevieve Aspillaga, who was visiting the seawall from Toronto.

title: Corpus Christi doctor suspended by Medical Board after public intoxication arrest
summary:
CLOSE Here's a tutorial on how to look up a doctor on the Texas Medical Board's website.
A Corpus Christi doctor has had his medical license temporarily suspended following an arrest last month after he was accused of being intoxicated at a Lamesa hospital.
On Wednesday, a disciplinary panel of the Texas Medical Board temporarily suspended, without notice, the Texas medical license of Dr. Rafael Fermin Garcia, “after determining his continuation in the practice of medicine poses a continuing threat to public welfare,” according to a board statement.
Rafael Fermin Garcia's Texas medical license was suspended after he was accused of being intoxicated at a Lamesa hospital.
The board panel found that on Jan. 5, Garcia was arrested by the Lamesa Police Department in the Medical Arts Emergency Room in Lamesa on a charge of public intoxication.

title: Polkafest celebrates 35 years in Corpus Christi
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, TX — Everyone is invited to come by the 35th Annual Polkafest, happening this Saturday from 11 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. at Sokol Hall (5502 Kostoryz) and presented by the Czech Heritage Society of South Texas.
Music will be provided by The Red Ravens, The Texas Sound Czech Polka Band, and Corpus Christi’s own Leo Majek Polka Band.
Sokol Hall will also be selling authentic fruit kolaches, with a choice of apple, apricot, prune, poppy seed, cottage cheese, pineapple, and cherry.
Doors open at 10 a.m.Polkafest celebrates the Czech culture and heritage, remembering those who migrated to Texas in the mid to 1800s and came for a better life.
To learn more, visit www.chssouthtexas.org or find the Czech Heritage Society of South Texas on Facebook.

title: Coronavirus in Texas: Abbott ask Trump to designate the state as a 'major disaster'
authors: John C Moritz Austin Bureau Usa Today Network
summary:
USA TODAYSo far, eight people in Texas have died from coronavirus as officials scramble to slow down the spread.
Greg Abbott on Monday formally asked President Donald Trump to declare Texas a major disaster, saying the spreading coronavirus is growing so severe that more federal funding will be needed to meet the threat.
More than half the money, $19.5 million, will be distributed among 43 local health departments.
The balance will be used by the Texas Department of State Health Services in areas not covered by local health departments and for statewide response action.
In his news conference on Sunday, Abbott did not rule out a statewide order in the future.

title: Patricia Branch
summary:

Patricia was born on May 28, 1954, in Kirksville, Missouri to Dr. Glen and Marian (Davis) Kumm.
She married the love of her life Robert Paul Branch on May 23,1974 and had two beautiful, successful, and loving children Richard and Jennifer (Shelepet) Branch.
Patricia is preceded in death by her father, Dr. Glen Kumm: sister, Cheri Kumm.
Left to cherish her memories are her mother, Marian (Davis) Kumm: brother, Denny Kumm: husband, Robert Paul Branch: children, Richard Aaron Branch and Jennifer Ann Shelepet and their spouses Christina Marie (Milbrandt) Branch and John Clifton Shelepet, grandchildren, Graceyn Ryleigh Branch, Jacob Ryan Branch, Madison Renee Branch, Zoe- Anna Marie Shelepet, and Xavier Alexander Shelepet and beloved dog Lola.

title: Police respond to early morning shooting
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Corpus Christi police are looking for two people involved in a Monday morning shooting .
The shooting happened around 7:50 a.m. in the 3700 block of Mueller Street, near Woodlawn Park.
A man and a woman living inside the apartment were in the bedroom there when the shots were fired.
The bullets struck the living room, but there were no injuriesThe couple responsible for the shooting fled the scene in a vehicle.
If they are arrested, police say the couple will be charged with deadly conduct.

title: One Man’s Struggle to Get a Veterans Administration Coronavirus Test
summary:
When White began feeling his flu-like symptoms the following week, he decided to visit the Veterans Administration’s Corpus Christi clinic.
“It’s just been my experience with the VA.”Like nearly every other health care system in the United States, the Veterans Administration has had to reorient itself to battle coronavirus.
While the CDC recently relaxed these guidelines and now allows doctors to “use their judgment” to determine if a patient should be tested, White still didn’t receive one.
A spokesperson for the South Texas Veterans Health Care System directed me to a different VA spokesperson for comment about the availability of COVID-19 test in the region.
Corpus Christi, known to tourists as the “shining city by the sea,” has the current distinction of being the largest municipality in the United States without a confirmed COVID-19 test.

title: Padre Island National Seashore announces Malaquite Beach Campground will be closed until further notice
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Authorities from Padre Island National Seashore announced new operations they plan to implement under the latest guidance from the White House, Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC), and local and state authorities.
"As of Tuesday, March 24, 2020, the Malaquite Beach Campground will be closed until further notice.
Where it is possible to adhere to the latest health guidance, the Bird Island Basin campground will remain open and camping will be allowed on North and South Beaches," said Chuck of Padre Island National Seashore.
According to officials, the health and safety of their visitors, employees, volunteers, and partners at Padre Island National Seashore is their number one priority.
"The National Park Service is working with the federal, state, and local authorities to closely monitor the novel coronavirus situation.

summary:

title: Brian Stephen Drake, 45
summary:
March 19, 2020 1:00 AMOur dearest, Brian Stephen Drake, went home to be with the Lord on Thursday, March 12, 2020.
Brian grew up in Jackson, Miss., where he attended First Presbyterian Day School and Jackson Prep.
They wed in 1999 and moved to Texas, where Brian earned his doctorate in chiropractic at Parker University and Brian opened up his first clinic.
Brian loved and was extremely active at Heart of the City Church in Coeur d’Alene, where he served on the worship team.
As details are still being arranged, information regarding time and location will be published on “Brian S. Drake Memorial” Facebook page.

title: Remembering Terrence McNally, a Theater Heavyweight in Texas and Beyond
summary:
Terrence McNally, the prolific playwright with Texas roots, passed away this week in Florida from coronavirus-related complications.
McNally was born November 3, 1938, in St. Petersburg, Florida, to transplanted New Yorkers Hubert and Dorothy (née Rapp) McNally.
Though McNally left Texas in the fifties and returned only for brief visits, his influence remained deeply rooted in his home state.
And five years ago, the Dallas Opera produced the world premiere of Great Scott, which marked the final collaboration between McNally and Heggie.
Endless days and nights of rewrites followed as McNally delivered his final play, Immortal Longings, to the Austin theater, as Steakley recalls.

title: All GPISD schools closed by order of superintendent
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, TEXAS — UPDATE: The Gregory-Portland ISD will be closing all schools to all employees at 4 p.m. Friday.
It comes after three district employees with the Gregory-Portland ISD have exhibited some of the symptoms of COVID-19, according to a news statement.
As a result, GP-ISD officials have closed of the G-P middle school campus to all staff until further notice.
The District believes the employees were at GP middle school between March 18 to March 20, 2020.
According to the school district, the results are currently pending.

summary:

The pandemic has also stopped trials in which the death penalty was being sought.

summary:

Twenty-five years later, Selena’s family and fans have kept her memory alive.
And outside of music, Selena was looking to expand Selena Etc, a boutique brand that she launched the year prior with stores in San Antonio and her hometown of Corpus Christi, Texas.

title: Terrence McNally, 81, dies of coronavirus-related complications
authors: Mike Boehm Is A Former Arts Reporter
Pop Music Critic For The Los Angeles Times.
summary:
Terrence McNally, whose long, varied and prolific career as a playwright, musical librettist and screenwriter earned him five Tony Awards and an Emmy, died Tuesday.
McNally, once referred to as “the quintessential man of the theater” by actress Zoe Caldwell, died from complications related to the coronavirus, his publicist Matt Polk said.
But the plays he wrote during his extended creative high tide were funny, warm, poignant, life-affirming and popular.
“When I’m writing, I try not to think in terms of themes,” McNally told the New York Times in 2004.
Actor Nathan Lane, left, and playwright Terrence McNally often worked together.

title: 36-year-old man hit by semi-trailer, killed
summary:
REFUGIO, TEXAS — A fatal crash claimed the life of a Sugarland resident.
According to a DPS report, the crash happened on US 77, five miles North of Refugio, at 5 am March 24, 2020.
The report states a pedestrian, who had been driving a 2013 Hyundai Elantra traveling south on US 77, ran out of gas.
The report continued a 2007 Kenworth truck tractor semi-trailer was also traveling south on US 77 and struck the pedestrian while he was standing by the driver’s side door.
DPS Troopers are still investigating the fatal crash.

title: A Life Surrounded by Vinyl Records
summary:
My mom had one of those music subscriptions that sent you records in the mail, so she had a lot of records.
And I thought, “Hey, I’ll be a DJ.” Not a radio DJ, like my uncle’s cousin—I’d be a DJ with two turntables who plays at clubs and parties.
And maybe that something was my vinyl collection.
Because I like having the records around and, really, who’s going to haul four tons of records across the country?
I was inspired by my uncle’s garage in Beeville, the one where he stored all his beloved vinyl that’s now mine.

title: Two coronavirus cases in Aransas County were false, official number returns to zero
summary:
ROCKPORT, Texas — Two confirmed COVID-19 cases in Aransas County were announced by officials Monday, but according to Rockport Mayor Patrick Rios, the numbers were reported in error.
A map posted on the Texas Department of Health Services Monday showed two cases in Aransas County.
Officials there said they don't know why or how it happened, but it has since been corrected.
The mayor told 3News the official numbers on the Texas Department of Health Services website has been updated.
There are currently no cases of COVID-19 in Aransas County.

Chef Tony Nichols was looking for a way to help support his employees and also help the community, especially the men and women who are out there saving lives.
He's the owner of Chef Tony's Custom Cuisine, The Exchange, Muchiez Food Truck and a kitchen facility at Coast Guard by the Airport.

summary:

According to Goodwill officials, stores and donation stations have been closed to the public since Monday, March 23rd.
When donations are exposed to the elements, it tends to make them unusable," said John Owen, President & CEO, Goodwill Industries of South Texas.
Until then, we urge donors to hold on to their donations,” added John Owen, President & CEO, Goodwill Industries of South Texas.

title: Executive order postpones elective surgeries in Texas
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, TEXAS — On Sunday, Texas Governor Greg Abbott issued an order for all hospitals to postpone all surgeries that are not immediately and medically necessary.
Texas health care facilities also halted unnecessary surgeries to save resources and keep hospitals at a functional capacity in case a COVID-19 disaster were to arise in the area.
Coastal Bend resident Vanessa Nisbit was supposed to have a gastric bypass on Tuesday morning.
Nisbit says just four days before having gastric bypass her doctor called her and said, "Due to the virus, your surgery has been canceled.
The executive order by Governor Abbott will remain in effect until April 21.

title: Local restaurants prep for major changes
summary:

"We're about one week into some significant changes we're down like a lot of restaurants like 50-60%," Jason Rodriguez, co-owner of Hester's Cafe said.

"We talked with our employees about who needs the hours, who is fine without the hours," Rodriguez said.

title: Police arrest Corpus Christi man for outstanding warrant in connection with recent homicide
summary:
MCALLEN, Texas — The U.S.
Marshals Gulf Coast Violent Offender Fugitive Task Force along with the Corpus Christi Police Department, McAllen Police Department, Texas DPS Troopers, and McAllen Task Force arrested a Corpus Christi man for an outstanding warrant in connection with a recent homicide.
On Friday, March 6, 2020 authorities apprehended 19-year-old Detavion Falkquay at a residence located on the 1000 block of Pecan in McAllen, Texas.
Officers apprehended Falkquay without incident and he was booked into the Hidalgo County Jail for murder on a $150,000 bond, according to authorities.
Falkquay was wanted in connection with a recent homicide that occurred on March 4 in Corpus Christi on the 4100 block of Brett St.RELATED: Victim in Brett Street homicide identified, police still looking for leads"This is still an active and ongoing investigation and if anyone has any additional information related to this Homicide, you are asked to contact the Corpus Christi Police Department at (361) 886-2600," stated police.

title: Corpus Christi police officer involved in shooting near SPID, Everhart Road
summary:
Corpus Christi police are investigating an officer-involved shooting that took place late Saturday on the city's southside.
Senior officer Gena Peña, a department spokeswoman, said the incident occurred at 8:08 p.m. in the 4700 block of South Padre Island Drive and Everhart Road.
Area news (Photo: contributed)The driver of the vehicle then drove in the direction of one of the officers, Peña said.
If found, the driver could face charges, including aggravated assault and aggravated assault of a peace officer, Peña said.
Peña said the officer who fired his weapon will be put on paid administrative leave as officials investigate the cause of the shooting.

title: CASA volunteers complete training for remote operations
summary:
The non-profit, CASA of the Coastal Bend, serves over 400 children in Nueces and Aransas counties.
To continue operations under the social distancing guidelines, CASA of the Coastal Bend has joined thousands of other businesses and nonprofits allowing employees to telecommute.
And though staff and volunteers find it somewhat problematic that they can't physically see their child, they're determined to make it work.
The organization quickly came up with the emergency health crisis plan to go completely virtual to protect their staff, volunteers and children from the possible transmission of COVID-19.
CASA directors say the organization wouldn’t be possible without their volunteers so it’s important for them to become familiar with the new technology.

title: Port of Corpus Christi says it’s set to slash spending
summary:
America’s biggest oil-export hub is poised to slash spending and possibly defer more than one-third of its 2020 capital budget amid the worst price rout in nearly three decades.
Texas’ Port of Corpus Christi, which recently surpassed Houston to become the country’s largest source of U.S. crude exports, is bracing for its customers to start cutting back after global oil prices cratered this week.
“Certainly you can expect there’s going to be a hit on exports,” said Sean Strawbridge, the port’s chief executive officer.
The port was responsible for about 40% of total U.S. oil exports in January, or about 1.38 million barrels a day.
For now, Strawbridge has identified about $100 million of the port’s $275 million capital spending program that can be deferred to next year if needed, although no decisions have been made.

title: Volunteers sew masks for health workers facing shortages
summary:
CHICAGO — Bill Purdue waterproofs basements for a living, but he has spent the past few days in his buddy’s Washington, Indiana, auto trim and upholstery shop cutting rectangles of cotton fabric that his friend sews into face masks.
Fashion designer Briana Danyele left Italy last month to return to her mother’s Greer, South Carolina, home, where she has turned the living room into a mini sewing factory, making masks that she embroiders with the words, “We Got This!”They’re among scores of people answering pleas from hospitals, doctors and nurses so desperate for personal protective equipment amid the viral pandemic that they’ve turned to the public, saying do-it-yourself face masks are better than nothing.
And for those sitting at home worrying as the virus strains hospitals and the economy teeters, sewing masks makes them feel less helpless.
“Whatever it takes to get the job done, that’s what I want to do,” said Purdue, 57, whose daughter works at the women’s hospital in Evansville, Indiana.
He and his friend Mike Rice responded to a Facebook post last week from Deaconess Health System in Evansville asking the public for help.

title: Chloroquine, Past and Present
summary:
Now that chloroquine is in the news everywhere, I thought it might be interesting to have a closer look at the compound.
Chloroquine’s fame is as an antimalarial drug, and the history of antimalarials starts of course with quinine (at right).
This was later considered a major mistake (the “resochin error”, using the drug’s German trade name), as it became a major antimalarial drug after World War II.
It was considered a major advance in that it had strong antimalarial activity and didn’t actually make people change into various rainbow colors.
So if you see someone confidently explaining just how chloroquine exerts whatever antiviral activity it may have, feel free to go read something else.

title: Coast Guard suspends search for owner of adrift kayak
summary:
Corpus ChristiThe U.S. Coast Guard on Monday suspended its search for the owner of a kayak found floating adrift over the weekend.
The search began on Sunday after an unmanned and adrift kayak was found near Aransas Pass with gear and lights on board, a news release from the Coast Guard said.
The area was searched by the Coast Guard Air Station Corpus Christi MH-65 Dolphin helicopter crew, the Port Aransas Response Boat-Small boat crew, and Texas Parks and Wildlife Department personnel, the release said.
The search will remain suspended, pending new information, said the release.
Anyone with information about the owner of the kayak should contact the Coast Guard Sector/Air Station Corpus Christi Command Center at 361-939-0450.

title: Aransas Pass private port processes 60,000 tons of cargo
summary:
Rockport Terminals LLC reports that its private port at Aransas Pass, near Corpus Christi, Texas, processed and transloaded over 60,000 tons of bulk liquid and pipeline pipe in Nov/Dec 2019—the first bulk product moved through the facility in 12 years.
The Aransas Pass property was previously owned by Nilok Chemicals, which closed and dismantled the carbon black smelter that had operated there since.
Bulk goods handler, CMC, from Louisiana, moved operations to Rockport Terminals and will use it as its logistics bulk goods trans-load base.
Rockport Terminals says that over 60,000 tons of affected soil was removed and remediated in the process of completing the clean-up.
Rockport Terminals is looking for partners or tenants to help further develop the property.

title: WEATHER BLOG: First front in sight for South Texas
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — On the heels of the second hottest September on record in Corpus Christi, many folks in the Coastal Bend are craving, hoping, wishing, demanding a cold front comes to save us from the grips of Summer.
September high temperatures compared to average in Corpus Christi, 2019kiiiHottest Septembers on record - Corpus ChristikiiiI've deemed the search for the first cold front, 'The Hunt for Cold October'.
To the delight of many, including myself, forecast model guidance is suggesting the first cold front of the season will make it to South Texas early next week (October 7/8).
The associated cold front, based on current data, would move in to South Texas either Monday October 7, or Tuesday October 8.
Eventually, South Texas weather becomes very nice in the later parts of October as average highs top out in the low 80s and overnight lows in the lower 60s.

title: Forecast takes us from Summer to Fall
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The strongest cold front of the season will arrive around noon on Friday and finally make it feel like Fall for a couple of days in South Texas.
Strong northerly winds are expected behind the front so boating is not advisable behind the front Friday through Saturday night.
Tonight will be breezy sticky and warmer with a low of 76.
Thursday will be mostly sunny by afternoon breezy again hot and humid with a high of 93.
Friday night and Saturday morning will be rather windy and chilly with temperatures dropping into the mid 50's and the lowest levels in 6 months.

summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — A naval air station in Texas says one person is in custody after an unauthorized person on base prompted a lockdown.
There are no reports of injuries at the Naval Air Station Corpus Christi, but the base said Monday morning that the lockdown will remain in effect until the base is confirmed safe.
The base says the facility went on lockdown at about 7 a.m. Monday after an unauthorized person who was possibly armed made it onto the grounds.
In February, a man was fatally shot at the base after he drove through a gate at the naval air station.
In that case, the man was driving a vehicle that had been reported stolen and led authorities on a chase before crashing into a barrier at the base’s north gate.

summary:

It was just before 2:30 a.m. when a woman reported to police that she had been carjacked on Panama Drive.
Officers responded and ended up chasing the suspects until they crashed outside a home in the 6900 block of Southhaven Drive, where they fled on foot.
Eventually, they decided to kick her out of the car and take it, so that is when she called the police.
Police said they have identified the suspects but no arrests have been made.

title: Quintanilla Family Cancels Fiesta de la Flor, Corpus Christi Festival Dedicated to Selena
summary:
click to enlarge Facebook / SelenaThe festival dedicated to Selena Quintanilla-Perez, the Queen of Tejano, is no more.KENS 5 this week reported that the annual Fiesta de la Flor — held annually in downtown Corpus Christi for the past fast five years — has been canceled .
The event, which welcomed hundreds of thousands of attendees yearly, usually takes place in April in honor of the singer's April 16 birthday.In October 2019, festival organizer Q Productions announced that the event would no longer be held in Corpus Christi, Selena's hometown.
Though the news was announced as if the gathering could move to another city, a public relations director for Q Productions told KENS 5 that "there is no more Fiesta de la Flor festival" when the news station requested more details.
Q Productions was founded in 1993 by Selena's father, Abraham Quintanilla Jr.
The company still operates the Selena museum in Corpus Christi, sells merchandise inspired by the late singer and is involved in the upcoming Netflix project

The Dia de los Muertos Street Festival is hosted by K Space Contemporary, along with many area sponsors.
Día de los Muertos, translated from Spanish to English to mean "Day of the Dead," is an annual celebration in which families can honor and remember loved ones who have died.
Graves of loved ones are cleaned, and altars are built and decorated with photos, favorite foods or drinks, stories, and mementos to honor them.

title: Elections in Texas: Voters approve 9 of 10 constitutional amendments

summary:

Critics said the measure was a gimmick, because constitutional amendments are already decided by a popular vote.
But voters by a 3-1 margin made it clear that a state income tax remains taboo in Texas.

title: Why should you vote? Here are the reasons the Nov. 5 election is important to Texans
summary:
Texans have at least 10 good reasons to vote in this odd-numbered year.
It wouldn't prohibit a state income tax, though it would make what's already prohibitively unlikely, prohibitively more so.
This amendment would require a two-thirds instead of a simple majority of the Legislature to put an income tax before voters.
At worst, it's a yoke on future generations of Texans whose challenges maybe different and better-served by an income tax.
We Texans pay a huge price in property tax to be able to say we don't have an income tax.

title: Bodies Of New Hampshire Couple Found Buried At Texas Beach
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas (CBSDFW.COM/AP) — The two bodies found buried at a South Texas beach have been identified as a missing New Hampshire couple, investigators announced Friday.
The deaths of James Butler, 48, and Michelle Butler, 46, are being investigated as homicides, the Kleberg County Sheriff’s Office in Texas said in a release.
Deborah van Loon, Butler’s sister, said the couple most recently had worked as gate guards for oil rigs in Texas, checking vehicles in and out.
“We all loved what they were doing and they loved sharing it with us,” said van Loon, who described her brother as an all-around man.
He had retired from the Navy in 2010 and came back to Rumney, New Hampshire, after he retired when his mother was dying of cancer, van Loon said.

title: State of the Port of Corpus Christi luncheon held at Solomon P. Ortiz Center
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — There was a sellout crowd of about 900 people packed into the Solomon P. Ortiz International Center over the lunch hour to hear from Charlie Zahn, the current chair of the Port of Corpus Christi.
It was the annual State of the Port luncheon -- a chance for Zahn and other top Port executives to update dignitaries and leaders of the local business community, who in many cases have economic ties to the Port.
Zahn told the group that the Port is now the third largest in the country in terms of tonnage, and continues to be the number one petroleum exporting port in the nation.
As for its local impact, he said one out of three jobs in the area is connected to the Port of Corpus Christi, mainly because of what's happening in the Permian Basin.
"We had a record year in 2019, and it's only November; but we had a record month, a record quarter, and a record first three quarters, and oil transportation out of Corpus Christi in 2019," Zahn said.

title: Record number of children adopted from Texas foster care system, new figures show
authors: John C Moritz Austin Bureau Usa Today Network
summary:
AUSTIN — The number of children adopted from the state's foster care has reached a four-year high and just over half of the kids were adopted by family members, according to data released Wednesday by the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services.
All tolled, more than 20,000 children left Texas foster care during the 12-month period that ended Sept. 1.
The number of children being adopted from the state's foster care has reached a four-year high, according to newly released data.
(Photo: Rachel Denny Clow/Caller-Times)Also, the number of children who left foster care outnumbered those entering the system care by more than 1,700 children, the state agency said.

The motorcyclist was dragged for about 50 to 60 feet before the driver was able to stop, Frazier said.
Frazier said the motorcyclist wasn't traveling at a safe speed based on the traffic conditions and he wasn't wearing a helmet.
All traffic is being diverted off the Weber Exit.

title: Utah man arrested after New Hampshire couple found dead in Texas
summary:
Courtney Sacco | Caller-Times via AP Courtney Sacco | Caller-Times via AP• November 7, 2019 9:50 amCORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Authorities say police have arrested a man in Mexico who’s suspected of stealing a car that belonged to a New Hampshire couple found buried at a South Texas beach.
Kleberg County Sheriff Richard Kirkpatrick told KIII-TV in Corpus Christi, Texas, on Wednesday that Adam Curtis Williams was arrested by authorities in the Mexican state of Jalisco on felony theft charges.
Authorities believe the 33-year-old Logan, Utah, man and Amanda Noverr might have had contact with 48-year-old James Butler and 46-year-old Michelle Butler.
They released a surveillance photo of Williams and Noverr crossing the border into Mexico in a car belonging to the Butlers.
Their bodies were found last week in a shallow grave on Padre Island, near Corpus Christi.

U.S. District Judge David Morales sentenced Boortz to nine years in prison followed by three years of supervised release, the release states.

title: #EndTheStreakTX: TxDOT's campaign to put and end to auto related deaths in Texas
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — November 7th, 2000 was one of the worst days for road related deaths in the state of Texas.
TxDOT is starting a campaign to raise public awareness called #EndTheStreakTX and hope drivers take notice.
The goal of the campaign is to end the deadly 19 year streak and to ultimately reduce the number of deaths to zero by the year 2050.
In the ten county Corpus Christi district for TxDOT, there have been close to 1000 fatalities since 2010 and 80 fatalities just this year.
They say most crashes are due to drunk driving, distracted driving, or failure to use seat belts, which are all preventable.

title: WEATHER BLOG: 2019 Atlantic Hurricane Season Ends
summary:
2019 Atlantic Hurricane Season RecapkiiiCORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The 2019 Atlantic Hurricane Season runs from June 1 - November 30.
This season saw 18 named storms, six of which were hurricanes and three reaching major hurricane status - Dorian, Humberto, and Lorenzo.
Major hurricanes are storms that attain category 3 status or higher.
An 'average' season yields 12 named storms, six hurricanes, and three major hurricanes.
This is the fourth hurricane season in a row with above normal named storms.

title: Fact Check: Is a state income tax coming to Texas?
summary:
Our KRIS 6 News Fact Check team looked in to Proposition 4, which if passes, would amend the state constitution prohibiting a personal income tax.
That doesn't mean there won't ever be a state income tax in Texas, but lawmakers call the idea "highly unlikely."
Texas is one of seven states which doesn't levy a personal income tax.
“Texas is still against the income tax, Texas is prohibiting an income tax, and we don't want it easy for somebody to put it out there,” said Hunter.
“If we're going to have high property and sales, the last thing we need is a personal income tax,” Hunter said.

title: Corpus Christi family awarded $37 million after wrongful death verdict
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — A Nueces County jury awarded Thursday some $37 million to family members who lost both their parents in a tragic house fire on Elvira Street back in January of 2016.
A defective space heater caught fire in the home of Martin and Angelita Enriquez, trapping them inside their home, where they both died.
The space heater in the case was made in China by the Lasko company.
Greg Gowan, Doug Allison and Luis Elizondo led the case for the plaintiffs, saying the heater was a "ticking time bomb."
They said they hope the verdict sends a strong message to other space heater manufacturers who would try to cut corners on their products.

title: Why Corpus Christi's port hasn't turned away incoming vessels amid COVID-19 pandemic
summary:
No vessels have sailed into the Port of Corpus Christi with sick crew members during the coronavirus pandemic, a port emergency official said Tuesday.
Corpus Christi's port has operated continuously in the weeks since the virus began spreading in the United States and throughout Texas, said Danielle Hale, the port's emergency management manager.
Port personnel have been working remotely and cleaning efforts at port facilities have significantly stepped up in that time to beat back the virus, Hale said.
The Port of Corpus Christi intends to widen this entryway, near Port Aransas, that leads into the port.

title: Port of Corpus Christi Closes 2019 with Success
summary:
zoom TSHD Ellis Island, Image source: GLDDThe Port of Corpus Christi, Texas, ended 2019 with record tonnages for December – 13.8 million cargo tons and 122.2 million cargo tons for the entire year, making a 16-million-ton improvement over 2018 tonnages.
“These record-setting figures are not only indicative of a resilient energy export market, but are also reflective of the large infrastructure investments made by both private industry and the Port Authority as we position the Port of Corpus Christi as the Energy Port of the Americas™,” said Sean Strawbridge, Chief Executive Officer for the Port of Corpus Christi.
“As we continue to be thoughtful in converting these once-in-a-lifetime opportunities into job-creating enterprises, we remain steadfast in our commitment to serving all our customers through creating value and certainty for their businesses.”Additional milestones in 2019 included the commencement of the long-awaited Corpus Christi Ship Channel Improvement Project, a near fully funded federal project to deepen the main channel to 54 feet mean lower low water, and widen the Channel to 530 feet plus 200 feet of barge shelves.
The port also received the largest Liebherr ship-to-shore portal crane in North America in December 2019, saw the substantial completion of a new cement import facility designed for nearly 1 million tons per annum, and signed the largest marine terminal lease agreement in its 94-year history for a new crude export terminal designed to handle the Very Large Crude Carriers on Harbor Island in Port Aransas.

title: Riding the energy wave
summary:
In late 2019, production levels in the Permian reached 4.7 million bpd and 17 billion ft3/d of gas.
In mid-2019, Energy Transfer Partners announced plans to build a Very Large Crude Carrier (VLCC) terminal at its existing facilities in Nederland, Texas.
The 2.2 billion ft3/d line is now moving gas from the Permian Basin to the Houston region, Texas.
To feed the project, Enbridge will build the Rio Bravo, a 4.5 billion ft3/d gas pipeline from Agua Dulce to Brownsville.
US offshoreAccording to the EIA, crude output in the US Gulf offshore now sits at 2 million bpd, rising over 100 000 bpd in the last year.

title: Port of Corpus Christi Closes 2019 with Record Tonnage
summary:
The Port of Corpus Christi ended 2019 with record tonnages for December of 13.8 million metric cargo tons and 122.2 million metric cargo tons for the entire year — a 16-million-ton improvement over 2018 tonnages.
Year over year gains in crude production led to an impressive 26.8% jump in crude exports from the Port of Corpus Christi.
"These record-setting figures are not only indicative of a resilient energy export market, but are also reflective of the large infrastructure investments made by both private industry and the Port Authority as we position the Port of Corpus Christi as the Energy Port of the Americas™," said Sean Strawbridge, Chief Executive Officer for the Port of Corpus Christi.
A hearty thank you to all our customers for their unwavering support of the Port of Corpus Christi and the South Texas Coastal Bend."
I think we can say with great confidence that we truly are Moving America’s Energy™," said Charles W. Zahn, Jr., Port of Corpus Christi Commission Chairman.

title: World AIDS Day raises awareness in Coastal Bend, quilt unveiled
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — The public unveiling of the AIDS Memorial Quilt was held on Sunday, Dec. 1, 2019, at the Coastal Bend Wellness Foundation located at 2882 Holly Road.
Immediately following the World AIDS Day there was a memorial service and candlelight vigil was held at St. Paul's United Church of Christ.
This free display of The AIDS Memorial Quilt is being hosted by the Mosaic Project of South Texas, Inc. and the Coastal Bend Wellness Foundation.
This historic visit will mark the first time since October 1997 that the AIDS Memorial Quilt has been to the Coastal Bend.
“We’re excited to bring the AIDS Memorial Quilt back to the Coastal Bend including several panels that were handmade by local community members for their loved ones,” said Bill Hoelscher, President of the Mosaic Project of South Texas and CEO of the Coastal Bend Wellness Foundation.

title: Harbor Bridge Project road closure to affect northbound Brownlee Boulevard
summary:
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — A segment of Brownlee Boulevard will be closed between Leopard and Winnebago streets on Monday, Dec. 16, 2019, from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. Traffic will be detoured along Leopard Street to North Staples Street.
The closure is necessary for bridge construction on the northbound frontage road of I-37 for work associated with the Harbor Bridge Project.
Motorists are urged to be aware of the lane closures, to consider using alternate routes, to follow all traffic control devices, and to slow down in the work zones.
All work is weather permitting.

summary:

The Corpus Christi Museum of Science and History will be celebrating #GivingTuesday / #GivingCCmuseumDay on December 3rd.
The Corpus Christi Museum of Science and History plans to raise $25,000 by December 31, 2019, to begin upgrades on their oldest exhibits.
About the Corpus Christi Museum of Science and History:The Corpus Christi Museum of Science and History engages and educates the public in science and history through exhibits and programming to inspire curiosity, understanding and an enduring thirst for knowledge.
The Corpus Christi Museum of Science and History needs 1,000 people to donate $25 or more.

title: Corpus Christi man gets 60 years for taking photos of himself assaulting toddlers
summary:
Corpus Christi Caller TimesA 41-year-old man was sentenced to 60 years in federal prison for producing photos of himself sexually assaulting toddlers, the U.S. Attorney's Office announced.
Gerardo Fabian Ramos pleaded guilty on Aug. 13 to producing child pornography, according to a news release.
During the hearing, testimony showed Ramos produced photos of himself sexually assaulting two toddlers multiple times.
"Authorities also discovered several images and videos of child pornography Ramos had produced himself and attempted to identify those victims," the release reads.
The Corpus Christi Police Department's Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force, Homeland Security Investigations and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children conducted the investigation.

title: Texas construction worker buried alive, dies after trench collapse
summary:
GREGORY, Texas – One construction worker is dead and two others are injured following a trench collapse around noon on Tuesday at a construction site in Gregory.
Workers were digging using a backhoe when the collapse occurred, burying a 36-year-old man alive, according to KRIS.
A second man was partially buried by the collapse and a third man was injured after jumping in to rescue the two workers that were trapped.
Map details where hate groups are in TexasThe worker who was partially trapped and the worker who jumped in to help him are expected to be OK.Gregory police chief Tony Cano told KRIS the man who died went into cardiac arrest and was pronounced dead after being taken to the Northshore Emergency Center in Portland, near Corpus Christi.

title: Goodwill opening first ever Clearance Store in South Texas
summary:
Later this morning the Goodwill Industries of South Texas will be opening the first ever Goodwill Clearance Store in South Texas.
The Goodwill Clearance Store has the same mission as other Goodwill stores, but this new store allows you to buy in bulk.
The Clearance Store is a store that is a garage sale meets warehouse meets flea market.
“This building will also be the new home for our e-commerce, new goods, the distribution center, and now the first Goodwill Clearance Store,” said Goodwill Vice President of Marketing Marjorie Boudreaux.
The store will be open from 8 AM to 9 PM seven days a week, and with the opening of the Goodwill Clearance Store, there are now 9 Goodwill stores in the Coastal Bend.

title: From medical bills to tax relief, here are the new laws in Texas starting Jan. 1
authors: John C Moritz Austin Bureau Usa Today Network
summary:
AUSTIN — A new law designed to protect consumers from surprise sky-high medical bills when they are treated by an out-of-network medical provider almost went on the books with its teeth yanked out.
Senate Bill 1264 is one of a handful of Texas laws that take effect when the calendar page turns to 2020 on Wednesday.
It was nearly gutted when the Texas Medical Board sought to carve out an exception allowing high-priced billing to stand for out-of-network care if patients signed a waiver.
Medical debt: 3 mistakes to avoidThe medical board, the state agency that regulates physicians and physician assistants, got the message.
The measure was enacted in response to high-profile examples of sexual violence at colleges and universities that went unreported and unpunished.
